metadata.title: Plantar Wart

ICD-10 codes.B07: viral warts (ICD codes provided for reader’s reference, not for billing purposes)

reimbursement: No specific issues or information regarding reimbursement has been identified. Reimbursement for therapy will depend on insurance contract coverage. No specific special agencies are applicable for this condition
presentation signs and symptoms: Hard, painful growths on plantar surface of foot
Tiny black dots may be present.(7)This is attributed to clotting of the capillaries(2,7)
Plantar warts can cluster (mosaic warts) or occur singly in pressure areas of foot
Foot pain or discomfort in pressure areas during physical activities such as running, jumping, or walking(7,8)
Lower extremity or back pain related to compensatory postural changes to relieve pressure on warts with weight-bearing Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors

causes: There are over 100 different strains of HPV .(2)Warts most commonly occur with HPVsubtypes 2 and 4, followed by the 1, 3, 27, 29, and 57 subtypes(7)
Direct or indirect contact with HPV (person-to-person  or surface contact)(7)
pathogenesis: The virus invades the surface of the skin through microabrasions too small to be seen bythe naked eye(2)
The virus infects the basal layer of the epithelium, causing cellular proliferation andvascular growth of the wart. Weight-bearing  on the involved extremity causes inwardgrowth of the plantar wart

Several weeks to more than a year may elapse between infection and visible appearanceof the growth on outermost layer of skin. The incubation period for HPV can be up to 3months, although a wart itself can lie dormant for years(2)
The wart usually grows inward (deeper) because of foot (weight-bearing)  pressure

The virus easily spreads and can spread to areas around the body other than the feet, such as when the person touches theplantar wart and then touches another area of his/her body such as the hands or face(2)
risk factors: Exposure to communal bathing and swimming areas(8)
More common in children and teenagers than adults(7)–Prevalence rate as high as 10–20%(7)
Common in persons who handle meat(7)

overall contraindications precautions: Always respect the patient’s subjective complaints of pain. Pain relief in conjunction with cosmetic concerns is the primary reason for treatment
If the patient has diabetes, refer the patient to a podiatrist for initial assessment and treatment intervention(2)
When using salicylic acid, avoid higher concentrations in children or limit the areas treated at one time in order to reduce the risk of systemic toxicity

Contact the referring physician immediately if the patient presents with signs of infection (red streaking, pus or other discharge, tenderness to touch, edema, fever), increased wart size or change in color, or excessive bleeding from wart.(1)Plantar warts can bleed profusely when accidentally scratched or cut(2)
See specific  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/Plan of Care

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: When was the wart first observed? Has the wart changed in color, shape, or size since first observed? Does the patient walk barefoot on wet floors in public facilities, such as gym showers or pools, or share socks/shoes? Do any family members or close contacts currently have plantar warts or other warts? What is the nature of the current referral? Is the patient having difficulty with ambulation, balance, or other age-appropriate weight-bearing  activities due to pain and discomfort related to the plantar wart?

course of treatment.medical management: Medical management Typical medical treatments are cryotherapy with liquid nitrogen, curettage, laser, and injection(7,8)use of liquid nitrogen for wart removal. Due to the pain that is associated with cryotherapy, this line of treatment is not recommended for young children(8)surgical procedure using an electric needle that cuts away the wart. The procedure can be painful and patients are at risk for scarring(2)use of laser to cut away the wart or cauterize the blood vessels that supply the wart so it dies and falls away on its own. This may be painful and take a longer time to heal than other treatments(2)injection of interferon-alpha  and bleomycin directly into the wart, which will directly attack and kill the virus(2)
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications clinician has prescribed; are they being taken? Have they been effective in curing the warts? No evidence is available to determine efficacy of NSAIDs for pain relief
diagnostic tests completed: The diagnosis is made clinically based on appearance. Microscopic analysis of wart scrapings can confirm the diagnosis and rule out any other type of growth such as skin cancer.(1) Typing the specific HPV strain is not part of standard medical evaluation(2)
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies or alternative therapies and whether or not they help. Patients, especially those with diabetes, should consult with their healthcare professional prior to treating the plantar wart on their own. By selfdiagnosing  and treating without medical supervision, the patient may actually harm himself/herself. Overthe-counter remedies can contain salicylic acid, which can irritate, damage, and scar healthy skin tissue or worsen a condition that is not a wart(2) Patients should never try to cut out a wart on their own. This is dangerous and can lead to infection and scarring(2)
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Document any factors that increase the patient’s discomfort such as weight-bearing  activities (walking, running, jumping)
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document if the patient reports having any pain associated with plantar wart. If so, note the nature of the pain (constant vs. intermittent, sharp, dull, aching, burning, numbness, tingling). Does the patient feel self-conscious  or frustrated by the persistence and presence of the wart?
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much)
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (A.M., mid-day,  P.M., night)
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Document number of wakings/night, if any. This should not be related to plantar warts; if sleep disturbance is an issue, it should be addressed with the referring/primary care physician
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient may be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/ or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician (dizziness, bowel/bladder/sexual dysfunction, saddle anesthesia). Any history of immunodeficiency conditions or immunosuppressive therapy such as for organ transplantation? If so, what treatments has the patient undergone?
history of present illness.respiratory status: Does the patient report any shortness of breath at rest or with exertion? Does the patient require supplemental oxygen? Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe _________________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Does the patient have a history of plantar warts or other warts? Has the patient been hospitalized recently or had any illnesses or infections?
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask patient about other problems, including diabetes, cancer, heart disease, weakened immune system, complications of pregnancy, psychiatric disorders, and orthopedic disorders
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient about other symptoms he/she may be experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Does the patient participate in recreational or competitive sports? Does the patient spend time in a locker room or pool without wearing shoes? Does the patient use public/communal showers at school or a gym? Does the patient walk barefoot indoors and outdoors? Does the patient share shoes and socks? Does the patient attend school? If so, what grade? Does the patient work? If so, what are the physical job duties (e.g., prolonged standing, walking)?
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Does the patient report any difficulty with functional mobility and ADLs? Does the patient currently use an assistive device for gait and balance?
social and occupational history.living environment: With whom does the patient live? Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home. Stairs to enter home? Number of floors? Are any modifications necessary?

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting.) Complete a general exam as indicated with a focus on the items listed below
relevant tests and measures.balance: Assess static and dynamic standing balance and note whether patient reports pain when standing on the affected extremity. Does the patient alter single-leg  balance due to pain or discomfort from the wart?
observation inspection palpation includi: Document the color, size, and shape of the wart. Note the number of warts present -Plantar warts are often flesh-colored,  white, tan, pink, grey, or brown. Black spots or streaky lines often are present within the wart(2) -Some warts may develop an uneven surface and a cauliflower-like  texture over time(2) -Numerous coalesced warts on plantar surface will form tile-like  mosaic pattern known as mosaic plantar warts
Tenderness or pain associated with direct palpation(2)
relevant tests and measures.posture: Assess standing posture and note any difficulty maintaining equal weight-bearing  due to the presence of wart
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Assess bilateral active and passive ROM in the lower extremities

other: Modalities are not indicated for the treatment of plantar warts
Clinicians should follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital and what is ordered by the patient’s physician

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Patients with plantar warts as their primary diagnosis are not commonly referred to outpatient physical therapy. Physical therapists (PTs) can recommend that the patient discuss treatment interventions such as cryotherapy or salicylic acid with his or her primary physician Direct physical therapy will address the patient’s complaints of pain or discomfort with weight-bearing,  postural/balance and gait deviations resulting from pain, patient education, and prevention of transmission and recurrence
assessment plan of care.rule out: Corn (hardened plug of skin on pressure point); callus (yellow-grayish  thickening of skin at pressure point); onychomycosis (fungus toenail); diabetic neuropathy; peripheral vascular disease; Morton’s neuroma; lichen planus; molluscum contagiosum; seborrheic keratosis; epidermal nevus; squamous cell carcinoma; irritated acrochordon; verrucous papules; amelanotic melanoma
prognosis: Plantar warts often resolve spontaneously (~ 66% of cases)(7)but can recur in the same place, even after being treated(2)
Cure rates for individuals undergoing treatment are highest in younger patients with only a brief history of plantar warts
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Podiatrist or dermatologist for complicated or recalcitrant cases
other considerations: Keratolytic therapy –Suggested method for use of salicylic acid(3) -Concentration of salicylic acid should be between 15 and 26% -Remove thick keratin layer by abrasion or paring -Apply SA daily and continue for 3–4 months

Duct tape: the effectiveness of duct tape treatment has not been established –Researchers in the United States conducted a study on the effectiveness of duct tape applied directly to warts in children(4) -Fifty-one  patients were randomized to two groups: cryotherapy with liquid nitrogen applied to wart for 10seconds every 2–3weeks  for up to 6 treatments or duct tape applied directly to the wart for a maximum of 2 months -Duct tape was more effective at completely resolving the wart: 85% of those in the duct tape group compared to 60% in the nitrogen cryotherapy group -The majority of warts that responded to either therapy resolved within the first month of therapy

The traditional Chinese medicine YIKEER has been shown to be an effective treatment agent for verruca, including verruca derivatives(5) –The main ingredients in YIKEER arethe plants Brucea javanica , Folium isatidis , Radix Sophorae flavescentis , Lonicera japonica , Astragalus membranaceus , Fructus cnidii , and Galla chinensis
treatment summary: Cryotherapy, freezing and destroying the wart with liquid nitrogen, is the most commonly used treatment for plantar warts in the primary care setting. It causes very little pain or tissue damage, but repeated treatments may be needed(2)

Authors of a 2020 meta-analysis  compared the effects of cryotherapy and salicylic acid and concluded that although cryotherapy has a higher cure rate compared to salicylic acid, the cost-benefit  ratio favors the use of salicylic acid as the first line of treatment because of the higher cost of cryotherapy(6) . Problem Goal Intervention Expected Progression Home Program Compensated, antalgic gait and postural deviationsRestore normal gait and postureFunctional training _ Gait reeducation, progressive balance exercises (as indicated), and lumbo-pelvic posture training _ _ Integumentary repair and protection techniques _ Prevent bleeding, which can spread the infection. Apply a doughnut-shaped pad around painful wart to relieve direct pressure _ _

clearance of wart s: Observation assessment of wart: size, tenderness to palpate
improved, normalized posture and gait: Posture and gait assessment with symmetrical weight-bearing  and standing balance, resolution of antalgic gait

maintenance or prevention: Wear sandals or flip flops to keep feet covered at pools and locker rooms(2)
Wash socks thoroughly after wearing them(2)
Check feet periodically and report any suspicious bumps, growths, or lesions to physician as soon as possible(2)
Do not pick at, pull, or try to cut a plantar wart. Do not try to file it down or rub it with a pumice stone(2)
Wash hands carefully with soap and warm water after touching a wart(1)
Wear proper footwear to ensure pressure relief
